body:
The history of the Ukrainian-Polish relations in the XX-XXI centuries has a number of positive cases of mutual recognition and empathy on different levels – form the authorities' to grassroots backing. The Interstate Aviation Committee's investigation report on the April 2010 crash of the Polish Polish Air Force One aircraft, presented on Jan. 18, 2011, has also prompted a number of reactions in the Ukrainian blogosphere and citizen media.

Juliana Lavrysh, a Ukrainian author of the blog Mediakrytyka, provides a detailed retrospective view [UKR] on the topic, analyzing the Polish media through the prism of the Smolensk tragedy. She concludes:

 [...] розслідування квітневої катастрофи у Смоленську стало для журналістів справою честі. Оприлюднені матеріали не стільки засвідчують свободу журналістської думки, скільки перебирають на себе роль засобів боротьби за правдиве висловлювання. Смоленська катастрофа – не лише тест для поляків, але й випробування для Європи, можливість зрозуміти амбіції гравців сучасної “великої політичної шахівниці".

 [...] The investigation of the April catastrophe in Smolensk became a matter of honor for journalists. Published materials serve not so much as a proof of journalistic freedom of thought, but, rather, become the means of combating false viewpoints. The Smolensk disaster is not only a test for Poles, but also a challenge for Europe, an opportunity to understand the ambitions of modern players of the "big political chessboard." 

In a comment to Lavrysh's post, Taras Nazaruk notes that "[...] the Polish blogosphere is turning into a powerful media resource" as well and gives a link to Jaroslaw Kaczynski's first post-catastrophe interview [POL], which appeared on a well-known Polish blogging portal and civic watchdog, salon24.pl.

While reflecting on the issue, bloggers put between the lines a question - what, actually, do these loud debates on the governmental level mean, from what important issues they distract citizen attention?

For, there is always some more truth hidden behind the loud debate.
